annotations: Despite lithium-argyrodite electrolytes have attracted great attention due to the high ionic conductivity and relatively lower cost, their applications are hindered by the inferior air stability and poor Li compatibility. Herein, we report a Sn/I co-doping the Li6PS5Cl strategy to overcome above obstacles. The optimized LPSC- (cid:0) 1 at room temperature, and improved air stability. Especially, (10 the typical L6PS5Cl argyrodites are the most popular sulfide electrolytes due to the ultrafast ion transport and the low cost of raw materials [10]. Nevertheless, it faces some challenges that plague its further develop- ment and application. The first crucial issue is the unstable interface between SEs and Li metal anodes because the electrochemical

electrolyte interphase (SEI) film with the composition (e.g. Li3N, LiF, and LiI) will be in situ formation to restrain the interfacial reaction and inhibit lithium dendrite, when contacting with the lithium anode and cycling [25–27]. Meanwhile, the element partial replacement (e.g. Sn, Sb) of hard acid P with soft acid has also been considered an effective method to improve the air stability of SEs based on hard and soft acid 3- units are extremely base (HSAB) theory because SEs containing PS4
susceptible to reaction with water to generate H2S, LiCl, Li2S and Li3PO4 owing to the high oxygen affinity of hard acid (P) [28–30]. Therefore, the Li co-substitution

compatibility and air stability of SEs. In recently, based on the typical L6PS5Cl argyrodites, dual-element substitution in argyrodites has been presented and achieved the great progress. For instance, Li et al. intro- duced Sn and O elements into Li6PS5Cl and effectively enhanced mois- ture and electrochemical stability [31]. Liu et al. introduced Bi2O3 into Li6PS5Cl and effectively improved ionic conductivity and interfacial stability [32]. Nevertheless, it is still challenging to

In this work, we first propose a dual-substitution strategy of Sn and I elements to optimize the L6PS5Cl electrolyte via the incorporation of SnI4 in conventional solid-state reaction method, in which partial P el- ements could be substituted by Sn elements, and a part of S or Cl ele- ments could be replaced by I elements. The synthesis parameters and crystal structures of Sn, I dual-doped L6PS5Cl electrolyte have been systematically studied via X-ray diffraction (XRD), field emission scan-

The solid electrolytes Li6PS5Cl-xSnI4 (x = 0, 0.01, 0.03, 0.05, 0.07, 0.1), Li2S (99.9 %, Macklin): LiCl (99 %, Macklin): P2S5 (99 %, Aladdin): SnI4 (99.9 %, Aladdin) = 5–4x:2:1–0.5x:x were prepared using the planetary ball milling equipment at 450 rpm/min and 30 h respectively. The powders were cold pressed into pellets with the size of 10 mm under the pressure of 250 MPa and sealed in a quartz tube. Then annealed at 550 C/min followed by naturally cooling down. The annealed electrolyte
3. Results and discussion3.1. Synthesis and structural characterization of LPSC-xSnI4 SSEs

Fig. 1a shows the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of Li6PS5Cl-xSnI4 (LPSC-xSnI4) electrolytes with various dopant concentration via high- energy ball milling, in which all the major diffraction peaks match well with the cubic argyrodite crystal structure peaks of pure LPSC phase (ICSD#259205) without any impurities when x ≤ 0.05 [26]. But the diffraction peaks of SnI4 can be observed when x ≥ 0.07, indicating that the limit solubility of SnI4 dopant concentration in LPSC is less than 0.07 mol.

Furthermore, as a contrast, the simple physical mixture of 0.98LPSC⋅0.02SnI4 is synthesized and characterized via the XRD as shown in Fig. S1, where there are obvious peaks of SnI4, implying further SnI4 co-substituting on the crystal structure of LPSC via high-energy ball milling. Remarkably, the major peaks shifted toward a lower angle with the increase of SnI4 co-substituting amount as displayed in Fig. 1b, indicating an indicator for lattice expansion because of the replacement of P with Sn

(R < Sn > 1.40 Å, R < P > 1.10 Å) [33]. Subsequently, Raman spectroscopy tests were further used to investigate the changes of electrolyte structure as shown in Fig. 1c. The main peak is located at 426 (cid:0) 1 corresponding to the symmetric stretching vibrational mode of the cm 3-. Moreover, an additional peak appeared at 337–342 P-S bond in PS4 (cid:0) 1 after Sn substitution (Fig. 1d), which represents the characteristic cm Sn-S vibrational mode in SnS4 due to the incorporation of Sn on the

This result indicates that Li movement becomes much easier after Sn substitution in the LPSC structure. Thus, these results indicate the uniformly SnI4 co-substituting in the LPSC argyrodite

In order to find the optimal SnI4 substituting concentration, elec- trochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were con- ducted to explore the change of ionic conductivity of LPSC-xSnI4 electrolytes (Fig. S4). Fig. 3a shows the typical Nyquist plots of SS/LPSC- xSnI4/SS batteries under 25 C, in which the LPSC-0.05SnI4 shows the (cid:0) 1 and is about two times (cid:0) 3 S cm highest ionic conductivity of 3.9 × 10 (cid:0) 1) due to the expansion of crystal (cid:0) 3 S cm that of the

pure LPSC (1.9 ×10 cell by the substitution of P with larger radius Sn. Nevertheless, the ionic conductivity of LPSC-xSnI4 decreased with the increased the substitution level of SnI4 (x = 0.07,0.1) because the existence of excessive SnI4 after reaching the limit solubility may damage the ion transmission network [37]. increased from 18 Ω to 79 Ω after exposure, while the LPSC impedance value significantly increased from 37 Ω to 283 Ω. These findings indicate that air stability of the electrolyte can be effec- tually enhanced after doping SnI4 in LPSC.

Fig. 3f, it can be seen that the Raman spectrum of LPSC-0.05SnI4 elec- trolyte remained unaffected after 10 min, implying the structural sta- bility of LPSC-0.05SnI4 electrolyte. Due to the characteristics of high ionic conductivity and electronic insulation, LiI as stabilized the SEI layer can effectively sup- press the growth of Li dendrites in the electrolyte [45]. Then, we measured the XRD patterns of SEs after cycling of Li symmetrical bat- teries as shown in Fig. S10, where diffraction peaks of the Li2S phase, Li3P phase and SE phase all are observed in the two groups of samples. However, the diffraction peaks of SE phases in LPSC-0.05SnI4 after 6000

h are obvious stronger than those of the pure LPSC after 653 h, suggesting inhibited degradation of the LPSC-0.05SnI4 electrolyte due to the stabilized SEI layer. In addition, we also observed the cross-section morphological changes between lithium anode and electrolyte after a period of cycling as presented in Fig. 5e-f, where the Li/LPSC-0.05SnI4 electrolyte contacts closely with Li metal during galvanostatic cycling (cid:0) 2, while the interface is relatively flat and 200 h under 0.3 mA cm

plating/stripping perfor- mance are important parameters to evaluate the inhibition ability of Li dendrite nucleation and growth of SEs[43]. Therefore, the symmetrical Li/SEs/Li batteries were assembled to investigate the CCD with the (cid:0) 2. As displayed increased current density at step length of 0.15 mA cm in Fig. 4a-b, the Li/LPSC-0.05SnI4/Li battery has a high CCD of (cid:0) 2). 1.45 mA cm The results suggest that the SnI4 co-substitution can effectively resist dendrite growth.

Additionally, the long-term compatibility between SEs and lithium metal is further evaluated by testing the stable cycling performance of Li/SEs/Li at different current densities as shown in Fig. 4c-d. Compared with the pristine Li/LPSC/Li battery, the Li/LPSC-0.05SnI4/Li battery can maintain excellent cycling perfor- mance without short-circuiting after 6000 h cycling at a current density (cid:0) 2, which is nearly ten times that of Li/LPSC/Li battery of 0.1 mA cm (653 h). Meanwhile, EIS

measurement was performed to confirm the failure caused by Li-dendrites after long-term cycles. As presented in Fig. S7-8, compared with the classic short-circuit failure impedance pattern of Li/LPSC/Li battery, the Li/ LPSC-0.05SnI4/Li battery still remains normal ion transport behavior. Then, at the current density of (cid:0) 2, the interface side reaction and dendrite growth of 0.3 mA cm Li/LPSC/Li battery became more serious and the short circuit after 300 h. But Li/LPSC-0.05SnI4/Li battery

can achieve a stable cycle over 2000 h with a negligible overpotential alteration. Interestingly, the Li/LPSC-0.05SnI4/Li battery can deliver a very stable Li plating/strip- (cid:0) 2 with ping behavior over 250 h at a high current density of 0.5 mA cm (cid:0) 2 (Fig. S9), indicating that the satis- an area capacity of 0.5 mA h cm fying Li metal compatibility of LPSC-0.05SnI4. In summary, Sn/I are simultaneously introduced into LPSC to form a series of LPSC-xSnI4 electrolytes through typical solid phase synthesis, in which the electrolyte with a moderate SnI4 concentration (x = 0.05) (cid:0) 1) at room exhibits the highest ionic conductivity (3.9 × 10 the LPSC-0.05SnI4 electrolyte delivers temperature. Moreover, improved air stability attributed to the Sn atoms partly replace the P in 3- group. Remarkably, the in situ formed LiI-rich SEI at the principal PS4 the

anode interface not only can effectively block the growth of Li dendrites, but also promote Li transition. Therefore, the LPSC-0.05SnI4 (cid:0) 2 at room temperature, electrolyte can reach high CCD of 1.45 mA cm and the Li/LPSC-0.05SnI4/Li battery can maintain stable cycling per- (cid:0) 2. formance without short-circuiting after 6000 h cycling at 0.1 mA cm (cid:0) 2, the Li/ Even at 0.5 mA cm LPSC-0.05SnI4/Li battery can still deliver a very stable Li plating/ stripping behavior over 250 h.

Benefiting from these advantages, the assembled LNO@NCM811/LPSC-0.05SnI4/Li ASSLBs exhibit excellent rate performance and cycling stability. Consequently, this work will provide deep insight into the understanding of the modification Li- argyrodite electrolytes by SnI4 co-doping, which are valuable refer- ences for promoting the practical application of sulfide electrolyte based ASSBs.
